ref_criterion: Gives the typical timeline of incubation (1-3 days), the onset of symptoms on the first day, peak symptoms on days 3-5, and resolution of symptoms on days 5-10, while noting that lingering congestion and cough may persist.
gen_criterion: Provides clear and concise information about the incubation period.

ref_criterion: Uses a clear dating scheme that defines the days of a cold by the onset of symptoms, excluding the incubation period.
gen_criterion: Provides accurate information about the incubation period of the common cold.

ref_criterion: States that peak symptoms are expected on day 2-4 instead of day 3-5.
gen_criterion: Correctly mentions the role of individual immune status in influencing the incubation period.

ref_criterion: Fails to express uncertainty about the timeline. (Justification: They can be influenced by virus, biological variability, as well as individual health factors.)
gen_criterion: Correctly explains the incubation period and provides relevant information.

ref_criterion: Fails to mention that specific viruses often have predictable courses that vary from the common cold.
gen_criterion: Fails to mention the role of coronaviruses in causing common cold.

ref_criterion: States clearly that the common cold incubation period is typically 1-3 days.
gen_criterion: Provides accurate information about the incubation period of the common cold.

ref_criterion: Details the specific progression of cold symptoms: sore throat first, followed by nasal symptoms, and then cough.
gen_criterion: Provides accurate information about the incubation period of the common cold.

ref_criterion: Explains that early cold symptoms are usually mild and gradual rather than sudden or severe.
gen_criterion: Provides accurate information about the incubation period of the common cold.

ref_criterion: Identifies the specific days when cold symptoms typically peak, which are days 3-5 of illness.
gen_criterion: Provides accurate information about the incubation period of the common cold.

ref_criterion: Provides the standard recovery timeframe (7-10 days) for most common colds.
gen_criterion: Provides accurate information about the incubation period of the common cold.

ref_criterion: Explains factors that might influence individual variation in cold incubation periods, such as viral type, viral load, and immunity.
gen_criterion: Correctly mentions the role of individual immune status in influencing the incubation period.

ref_criterion: Recommends antibiotics as standard treatment during the cold timeline.
gen_criterion: Provides accurate information about the incubation period of the common cold.

ref_criterion: Implies that cold symptoms always follow the same timeline in all individuals.
gen_criterion: Provides accurate information about the incubation period of the common cold.

ref_criterion: States that cold symptoms typically resolve within 2-3 days.
gen_criterion: Provides accurate information about the incubation period of the common cold.
